description.text: My second chess set. Supports are needed for the Knights only, the rest print just fine without. This is about a 35 hour print and will take about 1/2 kg of plastic . There is some work to do afterwards putting it all together. I found that some of the parts needed a bit of filing in order to fit, try not to force anything. Especially with the pawns, they can be delicate .

Yes

0.2mm

25%

I recommend 3 to 4 passes (1.2-1.6mm) for the perimeter on the base and risers

title: A to Z puzzle to keep them busy!!

description.text: Here is a simple project I did for my two and half year old son. Just in time when he is identifying all letters around him.

I used
2 ply wood 30cm by 22CM 5mm thick
Using the CNC I routed one of the boards (DXF attached)
I printed the letters TeeBot.. 3d printer (0.4mm layer height, 0.2 infill, 2 perimeters.) I used most of my short piece left overs filament!!
Each letter piece is 4cm in height and 1.2cm thick
I will like to see others make /modify one.!!

comments.text: The creator can correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe that picture is a digital mock-up and not an actual 3D-printed product. If not then I would guess it has been printed in a professional lab. However you may be interested in reading up on vapor polishing (if your printer can print ABS). I'm fairly new to 3D printing also but I was able to use the cold vapor polishing method described at https://airwolf3d.com/2013/11/26/7-steps-shiny-finish-on-abs-parts-acetone/ with some nice results. Hope you're enjoying your new printer by now!
comments.author: zipitupuk

Die Datei mit dem Namen "... Hälfte kleiner" ist für Logbücher wie auf dem ersten Bild zu sehen.

description.text: This is a prop which I created for my daughter. It is based off an old train whistle and has been designed to hold a compressor blow-off tool in the body. The whistle uses compressed air to create a train noise and is triggered when the handle is pulled downward. The whistle is comprised of five prints which are assembled using 3mm screws and 4.2 mm. knurled insert nuts.

M3 Brass Knurl Insert Nuts Metric Threaded
Outside Diameter: 4.2mm, Length: 5mm (See EBay)
In order to create the whistle noise leveraged the work done by MikeP-NZ, published Apr 20, 2013 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77183

description.text:
This part lets you mount your extruder onto a surface. It takes the filament from the top and extracts it to the bowden beneath.
I've created it for a mount on an IKEA Lack table.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40

fix the cables

After placing the cables into the mount, fix them with some tape.

enlarge the hole

It might me necessary to widen the hole a little bit, so the extruder can be taken out of the mount easily and doesn't collide with the cables going through the hole.

Drill a hole through the table

My hole is something like 45mm

Filament Guide

The little slot will be used to take a little part that guides the filament. Otherwise I have it getting stuck putting it through the hole.

title: VESA 200 x 100 adaptor for Dell Monitor stand

description.text:
I wanted a stand for my TV, which has a 200 x 100 VESA mount. I trawled the internet and couldn't find one that I liked so bought a surplus Dell stand and set about making an adaptor.

The adaptor fits straight on to the Dell stand via 4 x countersunk M4 x 10mm bolts. I bought a stand suitable for a 22in monitor and its counter-weighted nicely (there's a spring in the arm to allow easy movement up and down).

The tolerances on the adaptor are zero, which means that if you print it out at 0.35mm like I did, you'll need to slowly run a 4mm drill bit through the holes and use a countersinking bit to get the bolts to sit flush.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed on a Prusa i3 Mk2 using Slic3r standard settings and a thin layer of glue on the bed.

It just about fits on a Mk42 heated bed. Just.

Designed on FreeCAD 0.16

I'm still learning FreeCAD, so this was a practial exercise for me to try out my new-learned skills. I originally designed it as a 4mm 'H' section which was nothing like stiff enough and it just didn't look good. I took measurements from the stand that I was adapting, then used simple primary shapes to come up with the design.

OpenLock/OpenForge 2.0
As I have been piecing together some scenery, found I was unable to lock a couple of things together. The slots would not stagger, or mezzanines/passages conflicted around corners. Created these adapters to "switch" connection spacings. Advantage of the 1" wide adapters is that was where the changes would occur, (those little double wall corners, that 2 edge tiles would work, but not as well) a single adapter would help the layout. With 2 of the same type adapters, I also could quickly mirror the two to change the connection spacing.

The corner adapter came about, because I needed a 1' wide catwalk/mezzanine and wanted to match the typical A wall on the outside. (thus the "notches" on the bottom to fit the corbel/braces in the corner for the murder holes tiles) The corner adapter also works with the Spiral Corner Stair to help match up to the standard E tile dungeon layout, or as an open floor penetration. Also the corner adapter is good to integrate into the dungeon E style layout the 1x1 dungeon fixtures trapdoors, traps, columns etc.

Kudos to Printablescenery

I tried different filament guides and all of them added force and vibration into the chassis. After a short while the filament made marks on the surface of the guides so I decided to design my own.
Had a couple of spare 628ZZ bearings so used them to do a rolling axis and a turning axis.
The design is my latest iteration and the one I am currently using on my printer.
I decided to design all with zero tolerance and if the axis are a little too big I would sand them carefully until they fit.
You need 2 bearings with 24 mm outer diameter, 8 mm inner diameter and 8 mm height.

description.text: This is the same as the original funky 3 tone whistle, only there is no outer air chamber.  This whistle blows straight on instead of curving the air flow around inside.

Print with 3 solid layers for solid surfaces, 1 extra shell on alternating solid surfaces, and be sure your flow rate and line spacing is set properly.
If you do not have your solid layer fill and bridge settings correct, the whistle will not work.  You can add a few drops of acetone to the solid surfaces and that will seal them up if they aren't working properly.

comments.text:
do you need supports on build? I mean removing those from inside would be a challenge.
probably putting model on the left would allow a print without supports.
comments.author: vasilyd

comments.text: No, no support is required, but your bridging settings need to be set pretty good

comments.author: Aclen

comments.text: No sound for me.
comments.author: tomulinek

comments.text: If you do not get sound, then the chamber is not air tight.  I know it sounds absurd, but it is a fact.  I have done it a few times myself.  If the layers are not perfectly sealed, it will not make any sound.  If you print with ABS, you can swish some acetone around inside and it will work perfectly once it dries.  I speak from experience on this.  If you printed with PLA, maybe you can spray with some clear paint or something.  All I know is that it has to be sealed to work properly.

description.text:
Needed a motor base for the original extruder to make a Bowden setup when I upgraded to E3D V6. I am using it with this motor mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039986 - Thanks Bakchos.
The push fitting for the tube that was shipped with the E3D V6 has a 1/8" BSPT thread (British Standard Pipe Thread) and as i could not find any adapters here I tryed to make one of my own by mixing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1644523 & http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1861535.
Big Thanks to Lancerevo21 & MarqKole & Bakchos for your uploads!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

comments.text:
Hi amarand, no, supports are not built in; simply print it vertically, as you see it on the picture of the green model. Set Simplify3d to automatically adds supports at the bottom. I have printed it in PLA, so I have no experience with ABS, but I believe that with the Simplify3d default setting it should be fine.
I used two different resolutions, 0.2 and 0.3 just to speed up the work, you can just use 0.2 for all the model if you want.
comments.author: pauerbuk

comments.text: I'm a bit new to this, but I need to print a pair of these off, and am a little confused about the supports.  Are the supports built in?  How do you orient this on the print-bed?  The blue model shows it oriented differently than the green printed unit.  The green printed unit shows a base/support?  Whereas the blue model doesn't.  Any special settings on the FFCP 2016 series to print this on ABS?

author: AMIRSUA

title: Left handed duplicator 6 blower cooling duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So another cooling duct modification/upgrade for the wanhao duplicator 6.
It REALLY needs more air then stock but there is not a lot of room to add a blower on the right side if you have a enclosure. and radial fans just are so weak.
SO, I put a 40x40x20mm blower on the left side :)
Gdstime 4cm 40mm 24v Dc Brushless Blower Cooling Fan

One issue is I made a clip (middle top tab) that only works on the Swiss hot end upgrade heat sink (it has different spacing then the stock heat sink fins) I might take that out entirely as it was to ensure no sag but the petg I printed it with is working fine. (also have a boot which IMO is a must! for best printing)
The heater core wires get hot and can deform any cooler that is close in, but again this is working just fine.
This is a first draft and I have one prototype running on my system currently.
Feel free to comment, offer suggestions, or make a remix.

description.text:
This prevents the Helmer drawer from leaving the box,
I like to let the drawers open while i use the tools from the drawers.
Often the drawer slips out and drop on the floor, this endstop prevents this.

This doesn't work for the top drawer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.32

Infill:

50

Notes:

Resolution doesn't matter, i've chosen that maximum that prints well.

Hole / pin diameter.

The pin has a Diameter of 5mm, the hole of 5.5.
While printing with a quite large layer height, this makes a snug fit for me.
If it doesn't for you you can adjust the diameter in the openscad file, or add a drop of glue.

assembled in use Assembly

You need to start with the most bottom drawer since its way easier to assemble the endstop with a removed drawer on top.

Pull the drawer almost out.
Take the "hook"-Part, hole to the top, side-wall to the outside and hook the bottom-hook around the slide that's attached to the frame.

then take the other part and push it, pin to the top from the bottom into the hole.

I use them on both sides but technically one should be enough if it's okay to you that the drawer slides out more on the other side.

comments.text:
Ok, sorry. In CHIP terminology its a DIP (HAT would be Raspberry). A DIP is an expansion board for CHIP (like a HAT is for Raspi). This one contains an MicroSD reader, an OLED display (the blue thingy about centre-ish in the pic), some buttons for controlling a menu, a power button, some GPIO controlled LEDs and a USB-serial converter. There is a link to github containing the eagle files.
I designed that dip in order to have a multipurpose CHIP to carry around -controlled by profiles- to do some work like portable hotspot, usb stick cleaner and the likes.

description.text:
A pop filter or pop shield is an anti-pop noise protection filter for microphones to reduce popping sounds. It is made of a base, telescopic arm, and two circular rings. The inner ring is where your nylon pantyhose (or any other thin material) is placed. The outer ring holds the inner ring in place by using M3 bolts.

The telescopic arm can be extended from 14cm (5.5inch) up to 22cm (8.6inch). The telescopic arm has 2 M3 bolts, which you may glue to the "nut" model.

The outer ring requires 9x M3 bolts to keep the inner circle in place. Well, to be frank, one bolt would do the job just fine. But 9 bolts make the filter more hard-rock look. You may also add M3 nuts to the outer ring, to hold all M3 bolts tight, but I guess holes into PLA are strong enough.

description.text:
Hi All

This is a pretty ugly extruder design, but it works.
Its meant to be hung on the side of a kossel clear and attach to the X braces.
I printed the middle pieces out of Nylon, thinking it would help the filament slide through.
I think the material is working fine, and don't see why ABS/PLA would be better, although i'm not sure Nylon is really benefiting the design in any way.

For now i just have my 2 extruders connectorized, so i can unplug one and plug in the other. Works fine for manual switching.

Maybe in the future I will add some relays to have it auto switch and add a Y in the bowden tube.

You will need a 606zz bearing. 17mm od 6mm id.

Using this i have successfully printed benchys using Ninjaflex through a 10-12" bowden tube. Had to go 9mm/s with 245C extruder temp but it works. Hardest part is purging filament prior to printing in Ninjaflex. I have to raise purge with PLA first, then go hot, like 245 ish, and slowly let the Ninjaflex push the PLA out, then it runs out fine and I get a nice but slow bead of ninjaflex.

Resolution:

0.1 mm layers

Notes:

Highly suggest at least 3 perimiters and using 0.1 mm layer heights so the filament hole comes out good.

description.text:
Yin and Yang Fidget Spinner (Thomas Sanladerer Inspired)

Materials Needed:
1 608ZZ Skateboard Ball Bearing (not included in Download ;P)
Print the STL twice in any color

Important Note:
You MUST print the STL at a min. of 20% infill so it can have enough weight to keep spinning. After you print both halves, they need to be twist locked together (no glue required) before pressing the bearing into the center of the design. The entire design is held together by pressure. Keep in mind that you may want to really make sure you have a clean part by removing any strings before installing.

I must give credit where credit is due! Thomas Saladerer (aka. Tom's Guide) was holding a live stream ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ABTAUMC4kzg ) about a week ago and during his stream he started designing his Yin Yang Fidget Spinner. Well, it inspired me to jump into Fusion 360 and design mine. At the end of the day, I am very please with the design and I wanted to post this for others to show that we can all learn from one another. Happy Printing and enjoy.

Included:
1 STL file (print twice in any colour of your choosing)
1 image
1 .f3m file

Printer:

RepRapGuru Prusa i3 DIY

No

No

.200mm

20+% Infill

description.text:
Inspired by make anything's last video I modeled and printed this fidgeting twister thing.

There are 2 spinners, the shorter one helps lowering the amount of contact surface between the parts making it easier to slide.

Spinners V5 have a .25 offset, spinners V6 have a .3 offset, if your printer is well dialed in ther should be no problems with the V5s, if you have issues try the V6s

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kUxZS61_hNE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yKA3RUNZ9fw

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

Core ~70% - Spinner 100%

Notes:

1 Print the spinner you like
2 Start printing the core and pause the print right before it starts making the top
3 Slip the spinner on the core
4 Restart the print and wait for it to finish
5 Enjoy fidgeting

Printing the core with a higher infill makes it heavier and lets it beat the friction easier when fidgeting with it taking only advantage of it's weight

Print the wheel out of TPU with 1 wall layer. That makes the wheel very soft and act like a spring against the filament. I prefer about 20% grid infill with 4 bottom layers and 5 top. title: Happy New Year!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A simple hand cranked "Happy New Year!" thing. Video at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-jsRoVokIZM. Designed using Sketchup 8 (free version), and printed in PLA using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings on a Makerbot Replicator 2. We're making a few of these things as simple party favors for our New Years Eve party.

Assemble as per "Assembly.skp", a Sketchup 8 (free version) file.  
All parts slide together except the letters, which were attached using cyanoacrylate in a somewhat haphazard fashion.  In any case, make sure the word "Year!" clears the bottom of the cam stroke!  
Depending on the colors and type of plastic you chose (PLA or ABS), you may need to sand, scrape, file, etc., and/or glue the parts in position.  With white and black, I found that a medium amount of sanding, scraping and filing was required.  With white and orange, the parts slid together without very small additional work.  Most importantly, the lifters must slide freely in the guide columns and the axle caps must turn freely within the holes in the base.  If yours do not, sand, scrape and/or file as required to obtain a free sliding / rotational motion.  
Questions?  Comment, and I'll do my best to answer.

comments.text: This is great! Have you considered turning it in to a noise maker by adding a strip of plastic and a paddle gear? You can see an example on the front page.
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: I did not think of that, but it is a great idea. Usually, I'm trying to keep the designs I create as quiet as possible, but in this case, you're right, noise would be a good thing!  Thanks!
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: I had to design my own lifters because the ones that came with wouldn't fit in the slots. I also redesigned the handle, made it in to a noise maker, and am going to attach it to my shirt tonight. Thanks for sharing this!
comments.author: FollowMeOn

comments.text: I've printed this in 8 different color combinations, 1 was too loose, 5 were great, and 2 required significant trimming, filing, sanding, etc.  I was concerned about loosening the tolerance between the lifter and guide since if too loose, the lifter falls off the side of the cam. Sorry for the problems you experienced, but great to here you overcame them!

title: ZX DANDANATOR MINI V2 CASE - CARCASA

description.text:
Diseño propio para la carcasa de interface cartucho de juegos creada por @Dandare (www.dandare.es), especificamente para la v2.x con puerto kempston lateral.

3 piezas:

  • Carcasa parte inferior
  • Carcasa parte superior

  • Texto 3d para adherir sobre la tapa (opcional)

  • Además incorporo el diseño del texto para imprimir en pegatina.

Eternas gracias a él y a todo su equipo de colaboradores, ya que fruto de un enorme esfuerzo, disponemos de esta magnífica interface para el Zx Spectrum y sus diferentes variantes.

LINK INTERFACE Y + INFO : WWW.DANDARE.ES

El ZX Dandanator! Mini es un cartucho de juegos para Spectrum.

Es un adaptador hardware de memoria (eeprom) externa para Spectrum orientado al desarrollo y distribución de juegos en modo “cartucho” y a la carga a “Snapshots” de software tanto en formato SNA como en formato Z80. Su contenido puede ser actualizado desde el propio Spectrum sin necesidad de hardware adicional mediante Audio, Serie-Kempston o Divide/DivMMC. La versión 2.0 incluye, además, un interfaz de joystick kempston.
Añade algunas funcionalidades como soporte de juegos 128k, compresión, librería de pokes, rom externa o congelar pantallas.

El hardware implementa un sistema de configuración y servicios mediante comandos enviados desde el Spectrum, lo que lo hace muy flexible para otros usos como la distribución de videojuegos de gran capacidad.

title: Drop-stop fix for Moccamaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Moccamaster always had a problem with the drop stop, the coffee always runs along the drop stop lever and on to the lid of the coffee pot. First cup always resulted in coffee on the table and the coffee continue to drive from the lever on to the heater.
After having my Moccamaster Technivorm Clubline för two years, i decided to fix this.

The mechanics for the drop stop is faulty from the factory and the drop stop only opens about one Millimeter when the pot is on the heater and the lever gets an angle that the cofee can run on the lever. My fix adds 3mm lift on the end of the lever. No more coffee on the table!

author: dave_root

description.text:
This is a heavy duty replacement wheel for my 80 inch Hanger 9 Piper Pawnee.
It should also work for most 3 to 4 inch foam / rubber tires for RC planes (23 -25 mm inner).
This wheel is designed to be stronger, having a thicker tire bead area and thicker walls.

Assembly uses 2 mm * 15mm screws, this is a hidden collar design. The inner wheel is put on the axel, then the wheel retaining collar, then the outer wheel. The two wheel halves are then screwed together.
note: the inner space between the halves needs to be very clean in order for the wheel to spin freely on the axel and wheel collar.
The hub cap should just snap in place but may require a drop of CA glue to stay on if printed with a nozzle larger than 0.2.

For best results print with ABS (PLA and ASA should work as well) at 100% infill, 0.2mm nozzle, 4 or 5 perimeters, 4 top and 4 bottom layers, supports are required.

I made a pentagon penholder with 123D Design, maybe you need one.

If you print one and like it, please click the link "I Made One" located to the right of this model and post a picture of your print.

description.text:
Framed within the project MecaduinOpen the development of the printer TWO, is proposed as a tool for institutes, training centers and Maker spaces or similar.
Framed within the MecaduinOpen system is based on printed pieces as the development link of all its elements
It takes as a starting point of the design the printer ONE improving its mechanics incorporating wheels with bearings instead of slides used in this one. It keeps the premise that it is very economical, with simple parts and easy to print and that the assembly does not require complicated instructions, tools or processes.
The result has been a compact machine, robust and very simple and logical assembly, with a careful finish and smooth and precise operation.
The printing time of the pieces is below 20 H, to the simplicity of design of all their pieces.

title: Kossel Clear Dual Blower Mount and Shrouds

description.text:
Hi All

Mounts and Shrouds for Dual Blowers on a Delta, specifically the Kossel Clear.
You will need M3 hardware and 2 50mm blowers.

Beware, the original design i tried had the blower motors closer to the magnetic arms, and it fried the motor. This design doesn't have that issue.

When you print the shrouds, i did 0.1mm layer heights, with supports. The supports just help it get started. Print it in the orientation the file is in, and add a large brim. The shroud kinda attaches to the fan, but i used some ABS glue to firmly attach it.

This design does help keep everything tight, and open up your print envelope by keeping the fans from hitting the X braces.

Simply mirror the mount/shroud to get one for each side.

title: Raindrop Bird House with Wind Sail

description.text:
I had to modify Scintilla's Birdhouse because I live in the Pacific Northwest. It can get a little blustery, and you may have heard that it has been known to rain from time to time. This design has a small awning over the door to protect from falling rain, and the perch and awning have a 'sail' on them which turns the door of the house away from the wind and rain if there is driving rain. It also has some drain holes in the bottom. I made it black to give a little more thermal storage for the early spring, and placed it up under a branch that will have leaves on it by the early summer for shade so the black doesn't overheat my tenants.

I also hit it with a coat of black "Flex Seal" to make doubly sure of the comfort of my guests.

I love hearing critiques of my designs so I can improve on them in the future.

author: Spettinger

title: Redesigned lower arm for shanes extruder

description.text:
This is a simple tweak to Shanes Armdrive extruder.
I brought the guide section for the filament as close as possible to the gear/bearing, so it just barely has room to open with the quick release.

Printing this in 0.1mm layer height with PETG, resulted in a very strong even in the very thin section between the bearing/gear.

Using this i am able to print TPU at about 30 mm/sec reliably.

remixed_from.title: DIY Digital Caliper Plug and Cable

title: Digital Caliper Data Port Connector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I used the data connector as a starting port, though this is a new model, I wanted to be sure to give credit for the original idea.

I am trying to get the pictures in the correct order, but the assembly follows below:

  1. Use four wires from a multi-conductor cable, (cat3/5 work well), cut the remaining wires off.
    a. Total wire length should be around 22mm (7/8")
    b. Strip wires back 12mm (1/2")
    c. Use a pair of fine pliers to straighten wires

  2. Insert striped wires into the holes at the end of the connector, then carefully fold them down.

  3. Find the approximate bend point ~3mm that would create the bottom to make contact with the circuit board. Keep your finger at this point and remove the wires from the holes, create this bend with the pliers.

  4. If the above step was correct, inserting the wires into the holes again should create a nice wrap around the end of the connector and fall into the slots underneath.

  5. Ensuring that the bare and insulated wires are in slots, carefully insert the cap using a pair of pliers. This cap will be a tight fit as to make sure the wires stay in place. *See note 10

  6. Next hold the bare wires against the connector and if necessary slide the cable sheath up so that it will make contact with the Strain relief.

  7. Using M3, 4-40, or 6-32 screws and nuts, tighten the strain relief down over the cable sheath to ensure the cable will not pull out of the connector.

  8. Using a multi-meter or ohmmeter test to make sure no cables are shorted together using the following checklist:
    a. wire 1 to 2
    b. wire 1 to 3
    c. wire 1 to 4
    d. wire 2 to 3
    e. wire 2 to 4
    f. wire 3 to 4

  9. Test cable for proper operation using a micro controller, oscilloscope, or a logic analyzer.

  10. Remove cap and add some adhesive to keep cables and cap in place permanently, can be done during assembly if certain everything is correct.

  11. Add a small layer of non-conductive adhesive to the end of the connector where the wires are inserted to the holes.

Flashforge Creator Pro

title: Prusa i3 mk2 - Fan Duct Improved

description.text:
First of all: I choose the GPL license cause the original prusa i3 mk2 uses the same license. I hope this doesn´t offend anyone - If it does contact me and we will work it out.

(the orange one in the picture is the original part)

I made this based on the stl-files provided by josef prusa and modified them just a bit.

2 differences have been done:

  1. The inlet side (facing the top - fan - when mounted) is a bit higher - around 1.8mm. This will close the slight gap I had on my printer and prevent too much air from coming out there.
  2. The outlet side opens like 1 mm shorter so the air is directed a little bite more below the heater block.

I have done a few successful prints with this and the cooling isn´t worse than before and the closed gap makes it a little bit quieter.

I can´t tell if you really need this mod - it is working for me and that was my indention.

And yes i removed the "HOT" Warning on the front (this is facing the heatbed while printing) to get a better adhesion.

UPDATE: the new "improved" version will print without support - the cheap trick here is to add 2 solid layers (when using 0,2mm layers) between the big hole for the screw head and the smaller hole above for the screw itself. This has to be removed with a drill bit or a small screwdriver but not having to use support - which is hard to remove inside the hole - is worth it.

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used ABS for this print cause PLA so close to the heater block might get molten (especially when not using the fan - as for ABS mostly).

For the small "stick" (from 17mm height on) you need a little bit of cooling otherwise it will get messed up. I´ve done this by the following settings in slic3r:
auto cooling on
fan speed min 10 max 30
disable fan for the first 5 layers
enable fan if layer print time is below 10 seconds
slow down if layer print time is below 5 seconds
min print speed 5 mm/s

You need some support for the screw hole, I used the following settings:
generate support on
contact z distance: 0
pattern rectilinear grid
pattern spacing 1mm
pattern angle 0
interface layers 2
xy separation: 1mm

this will create a small support for the screw hole. and cause the screw will cover it up it doesn´t matter if it won´t look nice.

You could modify the design by remove the bigger hole for the screw head and use a longer screw - this will not need any support then.

UPDATE: the improved version will print without support.

comments.text:
i have made and tested it. it has definitely improved the angle of the air blown - it is more on the filament and less on the heater/nozzle now, so thank you.
however, i have not noticed any change in sound or otherwise with regards to the air captured from the exhaust of the blower, perhaps the one you got with your printer had an issue? anyways - it is a really great improvement!

title: Jack Sparrow's Compass
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Jack Sparrow's Compass based on this http://www.disneyexperience.com/models/compass_model.php paper model. I designed it because even though the paper model is awesome I want to make a nice prop that is kind of durable.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I designed it with a 0.1 mm resolution in mind. I haven't printed it yet so...
The Clasp, Dome, Guide and Top pieces will probably need supports from the build plate to print but everything else should be okay without them. Use rafts if you want. I would use at least a brim on the rear fixture just because it is taller then it is wide.

Things you'll need

-Glue
-Maybe Sandpaper
-1.75 mm filament

Assembly

Any parts that need to be glued should be dry test fitted first.
The tolerances I incorporated into the design may be to small or to big so some sanding or filling may be required.

Bottom
Put the part Finder on the round post on the part Bottom.
Put the part Guide into the square slots on the part Bottom.
Glue the part Ring into the part Bottom.
Glue the part Rear Fixture into the back of the part Bottom.

Top
Glue the part Dome into the top of the part Top
Glue the part Clasp into the front of the part Top

To complete use 1.75 mm filament as a pin for the hinge.

title: 3D Light Cube LED lead bending jig

description.text:
This is a simple jig for bending the leads of the LEDs for an 8x8x8 LED Light Cube. The kit for building the cube is widely available. There are a lot of LEDs in the kit, and bending them using a pair of needle nose pliers is very tedious. This jig speeds up the process. Hope somebody else finds it helpful.

To use it, just put an led in the notch with the longer (positive) lead to the left. Bend the short lead over the the right, then bend the long lead down. I'm using a small flat-head screwdriver to bend the leads.

Finally got around to finishing the project, here is the result: https://youtu.be/wtGOkR42Fko

This is a sturdy mount for a standard sized (15.8 x 27.8 x 10-12mm) limit switch. Mounts directly to the outside plates rather than the carriage in order to reduce the number of moving wires.  
M5 nuts are held in the mount. I used M5 x 12mm screws to mount to the shapeoko and M3 x 20mm screws for the switch. The STL is a pair of mounts which are mirror symmetric to mount the switch in the same orientation on both sides of the machine.  
This mount places the endstop in the ideal position to maximize the travel without hitting the belt clip.

description.text:
This is my electronics case for a standard size Voron Corexy 3d printer. It is designed to fit the PSU, SSR, and Ramps 1.4 together in one package. All parts have been designed to be printed without support.

This case is intended to work with all of the electronic components in the Voron BOM. If your PSU does not have a 150mm x 50mm screw pattern, I've included the F360 file for modification. The Voron ramps fan guard will work with this case, but I've included a fan guard file that matches the vent pattern of the doors.

Wiring suggestions:
The case works best if wires are cut to length, but has enough space to fit full length stepper motor wires to allow for future modification/motor reuse. Inbound wires(stepper motors, Y endstop) enter through holes on the bottom of the case. The bed connector and fused power switch are snap fit.

Check out the Voron community and github:
https://www.reddit.com/r/voroncorexy/
https://github.com/mzbotreprap/VORON

Hardware for Assembly:

Case:
20 x M3 4mm(L) 4mm(OD) Brass Inserts (8 for case assembly, 12 for door threads)
8 x M3 10mm Socket Head Cap Screw

Case Mounting:
7 x M5 10mm Socket Button Head Screw
7 x M5 Drop in T-nut

Case Doors:
12 x M3 5mm Socket Head Cap Screw

Electronics Mounting:
6 x M4 8mm Socket Button Head Screw (PSU & SSR)
4 x M3 30mm Socket Head Cap Screw (Ramps fan)
2 x M3 20mm Socket Head Cap Screw (Ramps Board)
10 x Standard Zip Ties (~3.5mm width) (Cable Management)

Printer:

Voron

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

25

Notes:

Recommend ~1.2mm shell thickness, ~1mm top/bottom thickness, to ensure plastic for heated inserts and case mounting.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

First Layer: 0.35mm
All other Layers: 0.27mm

Additional required parts

To mount the servo:
2x screw M2x16
2x washer M2
To mount the whole thing to the turnout
2x screw 2,2x4,5mm
2x washer M3

Assembly
  1. Print the parts (you just need one of the files called ServoL_Schraube_Beilagscheibe_all or ServoR_Schraube_Beilagscheibe_all. The other files contain the same parts, but just individually).
  2. Take a thumbtack and cut down to approx. 50% of its height.
  3. Take the M2 screws and washers and mount the servo as shown in picture 3.
  4. Take the cutted thumbtack and the printed arm and lay them into the base as shown in picture 4.
  5. Affix the cover part, so that the arm can no longer fall out. Take care that the arm still moves freely.
  6. Do not yet mount the servoarm itself! First connect the servo to your decoder and set its maximal movement, so that the servoarm won't hit parts of the printed thing. (For the decoders I use, it is the value 26 in the CVs 515,516,517 and 518. Furthermore I changed Speed-CV545 to 32.)

Once that is done, but not before (otherwise you could destroy your servo!!!)

  1. Affix the servo-arm to the servo on the one side and the thumbtack on the other.
  2. Take the other screws and washers (2,2x4,5 and M3) and mount the whole thing into the turnout. If required adjust the maximal movement of the servo a little bit.
  3. Enjoy

print_settings.Notes:: I used pretty rough resolution (0.4mm layer height) because this part is not that visible. I used 100% infill because the part is relatively small and I wanted it as robust as I can make it. I used 3mm PLA filament.

description.text: This is a replacement part for a Munchkin Extending Extra Tall and Wide Metal Baby Gate (http://www.munchkin.com/extending-extra-tall-and-wide-metal-gate-white.html). The part is the lower hinge pin that seems very prone to breakage over extended use. I created the first replacement part from hardwood, and that did not last. Let's see how long this will last.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used pretty rough resolution (0.4mm layer height) because this part is not that visible. I used 100% infill because the part is relatively small and I wanted it as robust as I can make it. I used 3mm PLA filament.
You may need to enlarge the hole for the metal screw slightly. It is pretty snug. I used a 20min epoxy designed for plastic parts to adhere the metal screw in the pin.

I designed the part in Autodesk 123D Design. It is a simple design with only one cylinder (the pin) joined to a cube that has a hole for the metal screw (under the model during printing, see the picture).

The only critical measurements are the size of the hole in which the metal screw goes, and the overall dimension & fillet of the "head" as it needs to be able to rotate horizontally about the pin.

The top of the head could be reduced. This was my first version so I went for extreme robustness.

title: Stone Age Axe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My son is studying the Stone Age period at school and asked me if i could create an axe for him. Based on a actual artefact, i modelled a simple 3 part axe.

Print parts in appropriate materials - wood effect handle. stone head and material of colour choice for strapping. Just some glue needed to complete.

Please note: not to be used for hunting or gathering.

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

low res will suffice

Infill:

low infill

Notes:

I printed this with a 0.8 nozzle and 0.3 layer height. Its a little rough but does add to the character.

Supports are only needed for the axe head.
the strapping will print okay without but add them if you wish.

Print parts in materials and colour appropriate.
The handle can either be printed complete (if your build area is large enough) or in 2 parts.

Glue handle together, slide strapping over but do not glue until the head has been positioned in its handle slot. Pull strapping down the handle to achieve a nice tight axe head fit. Glue all parts.

title: Modular carriages for 4020 v-slot (for d3m-bot, d-bot, c-bot)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Modular carriages X Y Z for 40x20 mod for V Slot rails with Solid V Wheels (openbuilds). It was redesigned from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1839201
It is used now for my own D3M-Bot (remix of original D-bot http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065)

Carriages is suppose to use 3 wheels - Solid V Wheels (openbuilds) 24mm (bigger then in original D-Bot/C-Bot). The 3rd wheel is to be tightened by top bolt. (so just screw tension instead of eccentric nuts)
Use nuts with nylon inserts locking to fix wheels

X carriage has prebuilded GT2 mount places (use belt clamb from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065)

Y carriage has 2 variants to be used without or with LED strip (was remixed from D-bot)

Z carriage has 2 variants with shoter bolts and longer

Parts for X and Y carriages interchangeable. Z carriage has own.

Build guide and materials to be defined soon.
(Temporary use as refrence instruction and materials list from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1839201 )
There is only one difference: for single Z carriage I've used additionaly 1x60mm and 2x50mm M5 bolts for wheels. To fix wheels on bolts use M5 nuts with nylon locks

Just finished setup - looks & works like a tank :)

Update 24.03.2017: Added mount block for e3d hotend in files mbot_e3d_m1v2.stl,
mbot_e3d_m2.stl It has optional mount for fan.
The file mbot-radialfan-mount.stl and bot-radialfan-flow.stl is radial fan 50x15 mount and flow corrector

Update 18.03.2017: Steps file added

title: My version of Underworld Marcus Vampier

description.text:
Underworld Marcus Vampire! Enjoy!!
UP-DATE 3/8/17 reloaded file as a zip, and now figure is in separate parts for easier printing.
UP-DATE: 3/11/17 changed lower body part somehow it got mirrored so I corrected it.

Modeling the figure

I used Daz 3D male figure for the basic pose and shape. I then exported it to an OBJ file and used Pixologic Sculptis to import and modify the face and body. I then used Inkscape and Gimp to make the Belt buckle and wings, also used Hexagon 3D to add the boots, wings, belt buckle and skirt. A lot of work into making this model it took me about 2 months of work on and off and its still a work in progress. I'm releasing it to all in the hopes that you will enjoy my work, and encourage you to finish it or start your own. Enjoy!,

There is still a standing base to made and a support to hold him up I'll leave that up to you to finish, look forward to seeing your work. I'm sure you can use Mesh-mixer and use select to separate out the parts.

Cube version coming soon.

Canopy for the RotorX Atom holds a Foxeer Arrow and GoPro Session. Components used in my build:

Kiss AIO FC/ESCs
Crossfire Micro RX
Unify Pro HV w/ dipole antenna
Foxeer Arrow V2

Must use 5mm round standoffs, and the two front standoffs need to be 4mm lower than the back 4. This was to account for the Kiss AIO board, on top of 4 nylon nuts. Other then that, this can be used at any height, so the components used don'd necessarily matter. I used 15mm all around, and there is a 12.5mm gap between the bottom of canopy and the frame.

Tube at the back to hold the VTX antenna, small gab between the VTX tube and the case to run a crossfire antenna up, and then through the small rube on the back of the GoPro. Mount other antenna on a zip tie off one of the back standoffs.

Printed out of TPU, positioned upright (as it would be on the quad), with support. Came out pretty clean , there are a few areas that could be optimized (particularly the bottom of the VTX tube). Used:

18% infill
No infill in thin walls
.15mm layer height

Came to 16.5g.

comments.text: Hey! Thanks for the suggestions. The reason that I went with the top down is because I already had that go-pro enclosure designed for my other frames (Red20RC BDX and Kermit), so just built the canopy and plopped it on top. It works really well with TPU, with the flex, but could see how nylon would make it pretty much impossible. DM me on IG (@billnye_headyguy) and Ill see if I can make some minor mods to make it a little easier for ya. I can definitely do a little hole to allow for the rear button. Again, with TPU, I found that the back flexes enough to hit the button, and it was easier to print without the gap there. But if you're going Shapeways, I can definitely add that back in!

print_settings.Notes:: I printed at .3 layer height, 5 perimeters, 0 top and bottom layers and no infill. Using 0 top and bottom gives you the groove in the arms, but you can cap them if you want. 5 perimeters will make it a solid object so no infill is needed. The center bearing should press in with no fitting, but is tight to pop in, the outer bearings will probably require scraping. I use a pocket knife, scrape around a little bit to knock the ridge down, the try to push it in. The rings they fit in are cut out with a sphere, so they are wider in the middle. Just do enough so pop them in with a fair amount of force and they will stay in fine.

description.text:
These are fun to spin around on your desktop and let them smack in to things or each other, just don't use near your drink cups! You will need a 1inch ball bearing for the center and 5/8 for the arms. You can't really spin them in your hand like a normal 608 bearing spinner, but on a flat surface they spin a long time on the 1' ball.

description.text:
The Lattice Design Fidget Spinner is a classic fidget toy with a cool lattice design. Use it to keep your hands occupied while talking, in class, or wherever in a fun and non-annoying way! All you need is a 22mm skate bearing and 15 pennies along with the models and you'll be all set!

PLEASE NOTE: Depending on the accuracy of your print, some of the components may require sanding to work properly.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High Quality

Infill:

25%

Notes:

For best results, print the models with the highest resolution you can.

Assembly Instructions

After printing all three models, simply push your bearing through the center hole (sanding may be required but it should still be a tight fit) and insert the two caps through the bearing so that they connect together. Then glue three stacks of five pennies together and push them through each of the three outer holes (again, sanding may be required) to add weight. After this your spinner should be complete!

How to use

To use the spinner, place the center caps between your thumb and a finger (usually middle works best). Give it a spin with your free hand and keep your hands occupied for hours!

title: Duil Cups with wire stress relief and gap

Then I made a similar shape as an guide/insert/relief to also keep the wire centered in the hole and not keep snagging on the gap in the Duli Cup.

The Duli Cup with Gap isn't anything special. The insert should be printed in flexible filament. It will squish and should mostly close the gap in the mode.

description.text:
ThatEmuGuy did an excellent job creating the Swedish S-tank Stridsvagn 103 (1-100) which has an amazing level of detail. Unfortunately I was having some issues printing it and, like always with the Printalotapotamus I figured that if I'm going to spend some time working on the model to make it easier to print then I might as well upload it for everyone else to enjoy if they like.

I typically use these models for 15mm science fiction wargaming so I sometimes take a little liberty with the designs as well.

Changes to this model:

  • Barrel. It seemed a bit fragile. I sacrificed being accurate to the real tank in exchange for enhancing durability. These are game pieces for me and will get handled, packed away, and handled again over and over every few weekends.
  • Treads. I noticed the wheels of the treads easily snapped off the model and the treads themselves were very thin and had trouble with a good angle for printing. To resolve this I separated them completely, added a fill to tie them all together, thickened the tread itself, and added a little 1mm guide tab at the top of the tread to keep them from pushing right up against the body when gluing them in.
  • Exhaust. It was a very thin walled pipe which again was giving me more trouble than I wanted. I am more than happy to chop a few pieces off to make this work for my Gruntz games.
  • Headlights. The headlights were very small and thin. I gave them a solid backing but left the fine detail on the front of them.
  • Barrel-less model. I ended up having a heckin time printing that barrel even after I thickened it. It might be my retraction settings but the point that it connects to the rest of the model kept printing thinner than the rest of the barrel making it super fragile. So I've created another version that actually excludes most of the barrel. I'll be using a 2mm piece of brass pipe and the printed barrel end model to make a sturdy barrel that won't snap off. Enjoy!

I have laid it out already with supports and lined up the best way possible to print for you and included the separate pieces as well. I believe you should always print tank barrels vertically. They are weaker this way, but printing them horizontally makes the stepping of your printer layers VERY obvious and makes the bottom of the barrel a total mess. Another option is to use small 2mm brass rods or pipe for the barrels.

So there you go. Another EZ remix by Printalotapotamus. Be sure to thank TheEmuGuy for the original model. He did all the real work here.

I had to design and print this because one of my parts came faulty (the internal cuts were shifted relative to the border as per the second image). I managed to bodge it with gaffa tape however until I got this printed off and replaced it. This is what to expect from these cheap 3D printer kits, the quality control of the A6 evidently isn't up to scratch right now I guess. Got it working anyway though.
Hopefully this saves someone the effort of measuring and designing one themselves, or you could change the color scheme of your current ones.

title: Improved rebelix x axis end with tensioning

description.text:
IT WORKS! I am successfully printing with tensioned everything :D

I was tired of the stock x end not being able to hold the x belt tensioned at all. First i put a ziptie on it, then i designed and printed this.
It takes one m5 around 25mm long with hex head, one nut and maybe a washer.

V1.1 the endstop mounting holes did not line up with the z home adjusting screw.

V2 x-motor is now narrower, so it doesn't eat up printvolume. x-end has a bigger 6mm hole for the m5 screw. (if it's too much just use a washer, there shall be enough space for it)

Please let me know, if anythings needs improving or what do you think about the design. Thanks

title: DIY Nokia 5110 Display Design Clock with Arduino Nano

description.text:
This is a neat little clock using an 5110 display of an old Nokia cellphone. If you want, you can call it a smart clock, as many features can be programmed and load onto the Arduino micro controller which drives the display module.

I got inspired by the "Desktop Widget by smily77" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:857858)

Material For this project you'll need:
  • an Arduino Nano board
  • an DS3231 RTC module
  • an 5110 display module
  • two switches
  • some wires
  • some resistors
  • a summer (optional: if you want an alarm)
    and 3D printer - of course :D

** Casing **

The case consists of two parts: the first one is the body where the display module is snapped (and / or glued - depends on the precision of your printer) into the casing. The second part -the back panel - holds the Arduino Nano board in place and support the other components. Due to the tight fit of the Arduino you don't need to glue it in place, even if you plug it in and out!

** Hardware **

I've drawn a diagram for the wiring which can be found on GitHub:
https://github.com/meiniKi/Nokia_5110_Design_Clock/blob/master/wiring_diagram.png

Please consider that the display is supplied by 3.3 volts!! A 5 volts supply will blow up the display!

** Software **

The software is in progress and can be found on GitHub. Please pay attention to the frequent changes!
https://github.com/meiniKi/Nokia_5110_Design_Clock/blob/master/Clock5110.ino

** Updates **

11.03.2017: new software version available on GitHub

I like sharing my projects that everyone can rebuild and improve it. To present it in a way also not so experienced visitors can rebuild it is quite time-consuming. If you like the project you can support me by leaving some tip, so I can buy new modules and electronic components for further projects. :)

description.text: This is a replacement pedal for a kid's Schwinn tricycle. The original pedals are plastic clamshells which have a protrusion that fits into the notch in the medal pedal shaft. Of course, that protrusion gets bent pretty quickly, and then the pedals don't stay on the shaft. This replacement design has a reinforced protrusion and holds together with bolts instead of plastic snaps.

100%

Notes:

Print two identical copies. Use M3 bolts and nuts with washers to hold them together. The bolt heads function as tread, but if I had this to design over again I would have added some tread. Step file included, if you want to remix!

Initially, the friction of the protrusion in the groove introduces friction that makes the pedal spin stiffly, but as that material starts to wear down, it gets easier to turn.

print_settings.Notes:: You should be able to pop the bearings in from the bottom side without having to scrape the edges, it usually seems slightly looser that the top. If its too loose, increase the bottom layer extrusion to compensate. The outer bearing sleeves are cut out with a sphere so the center is wider than top and bottom. There will be a little play in them, which I kind of like because it make a little rattling sound when you hold it on end or move it around, when spinning horizontally it is smooth and silent. The 3 bearing design is my new all time favorite spinner. Hope you enjoy.

description.text:
Spinners using 608 bearing in the middle and 5/8 ball bearings for weight. Including some taller caps so when you set it on a flat object it will clear the balls and spin freely. I got a box of 50 ball bearings from Amazon for $18.25 https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007B2AD70/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
For my first test I picked up just a few from Ace Hardware, but more expensive buying them that way.
The caps in the pictures are the circle and crosshairs pattern. The plain (TallPlain and KAP4.1NEW) are just a smooth flat bottom.
Videos
https://youtu.be/hmLTzb4DPaI
https://youtu.be/9oPLGj8kDA4

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Notes:

Printed at .3, 5 perimeters, 0 top and bottom layers and no infill. Use infill for caps. I am still looking for the perfect settings for those, 100% infill makes them too tight, 50% is a smidge loose. Try 75%. I usually sand the tops (small center) on a flat surface with sandpaper to flatten them and make sure they don't bump each other from any nubs left from printing.

You should be able to pop the bearings in from the bottom side without having to scrape the edges, it usually seems slightly looser that the top. If its too loose, increase the bottom layer extrusion to compensate. The outer bearing sleeves are cut out with a sphere so the center is wider than top and bottom. There will be a little play in them, which I kind of like because it make a little rattling sound when you hold it on end or move it around, when spinning horizontally it is smooth and silent. The 3 bearing design is my new all time favorite spinner. Hope you enjoy.

description.text:
This is a simple headphone rest that mounts underneath the desk. I've seen cool designs on thingiverse for headphone stands, but those take precious desk space. I've seen cool designs on thingiverse for headphone hooks, but almost all of them mount to your desk with a clip that is desk width specific, might slip off, and again, result in a slightly reduction to desk space. This design mounts only to the bottom of the desk with two screws. It's surprisingly strong.

The screw holes are for US standard #6 sheet metal or wood screws. The thread doesn't need to bite into the hole, so the holes are slightly oversized (4mm diameter). I included the step file if you need to remix for your screw size.

Drill pilot holes in your desk, but be careful not to drill through your desk! I used US #6 sheet metal screws with washers.

remixed_from.title: Pergo's Robo3D (R1 and Plus too) Pressed Bearing Spool Holder

title: Pergo's Ver 2 Robo3D (R1 and Plus) Bearing Spool Holder

description.text:
Here it is! Version 2 more precise and stronger than version 1.

Wow it printed and assembled better than I imagined. Yes the first 2 pics do have the roller from my version #1. I'm printing the new roller now. Pics will be updated when done. Ya that's my old stock 8mm bar holding up the spool. The added weight of the steel rod vs the printed 7.9 mm bar is much better and provides a smoother roll off. I need to cut it down to size. Cut the screw ends off too. I only had 8mm long M3 screws which were too short and the 40 mm M3's are way too long.

Major changes are that ..

  • The top slot is now closed off to keep heat in during ABS prints.
    (See my Robo3D Head Chamber)
  • Much stronger and sturdier.
  • More stable
  • Uses 2 3 mm screws and a nut with a 5.4 mm clearance.

You don't have to print the 7.9 mm Bar, instead you can use a 8 mm smooth rod.

Please review "Print Orientation.png" for print rotations before printing.

These are the bearings I used, or you can print the 22mm spacer if you don't yet have the bearings.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010GI2ZJY $7.99 Prime These bearings are very smooth ABEC 3 would be good too.

pugslyyy used these https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C6OFIDQ

I think it's best to print all parts solid. 100% in-fill.

Comments please.. and let's see those prints. After all this is what made me decide to rework a Version 2!

title: Case with support for SainSmart 7 inch 1024*600 Capacitive Touch Screen LCD Display HDMI

description.text:
Case with support for 7 inch capacitive touch screen (SKU:101-40-192 | UPC:6959011562004). This screen connects via HDMI and has an USB connection for power and touchscreen functionality.

It attaches using bolts and nuts (2 x M3-30mm, 4x M3-16mm, 1x M4-40mm, 6 x M3 nuts, 1 x M4 nut). Additionally, it uses a 15x15 mm alu square profile for the arm that attaches to the wall.

You have the FreeCAD source. Use FreeCAD v 0.17 (it uses Part Design NEXT).

WARNING: My printed version was 1 mm too short and I had to rework the PCB (increase the holes to 5 mm). I have fixed this in FreeCAD. However, that also indicates that this version is untested. If you make one, feel free to leave in the comments if it fits well or not.

If PCB holes do not align

Drill the holes of the touchscreen PCB to 5 mm.

About this PCB, you might consider changing the resistors that regulate the intensity to 2 resistors of 20 ohms, as the stock ones (1 ohm in parallel with 2 ohms) are too bright.

Additionally, you might consider this hack:
http://capnbry.net/blog/?p=210

In the hack you can see the two resistors I mention above.

author: RPL_Launchpad

description.text:
To celebrate the release of another song from the upcoming Rush album Clockwork Angels two days from now, I decided to model the clock shown in the teaser trailer (see links below). This is the outer ring that you could mount on a CD-sized clock. I designed it in Google Sketchup, and made a mistake that I eventually decided I like, so I'm sticking with it - instead of the base being solid as originally designed, slicing subtracted the symbols from the base. The result is that the bottom of the base has a negative of the symbols, and then the symbols are still printed on top. I actually like it. Mine was printed with clear PLA so you can't really make out the symbols that well without good lighting, but hopefully it looks better printed with an opaque plastic. Sadly I am in no way connected with Rush - I'm just an insanely devoted fan. :) teaser trailer:
http://bcove.me/hwp437l4 different youtube link:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mK9PTQzopCA Update: Now that the song is out, here's the official lyrics video: RUSH - "Headlong Flight" - Official Lyric Video
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZcFGrWjOX0E

First, start playing your favorite Rush album (if you're like me and your favorite Rush album is whichever Rush album is playing, then try to randomly pick one). Print, attach to a CD-based clock if you have one lying around, and enjoy.
Bonus geek step: Appreciate that the thingiverse id for this item (21555) is coincidentally pretty damned cool.. the first two digits are from 2112, and the last three (555) are most often associated with the 555 timer chip (get it? time? clock? is this thing on?)

comments.text:

--> Another insanely devoted fan here :)

description.text: This is a mount for some aluminum channel from Banggood.com that I've been using lately for mounting LED strips. It's great stuff! Each 50cm segment only comes with two mounting clips, though. If you cut it in half, you won't have any way to mount the second half. That's why I designed this piece. It only works for the U style channel (as you can probably tell by looking at it. It holds the channel at the same height as the included clips in case you need to mix and match the mounts for some reason.

The X-axis belt is very hard to tension on the Anet A6 so I made this belt tensioner as a quick fix until I installed a much better one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1974412. The tensioner is designed to avoid colliding with the extruder assembly which was a problem I had with other tensioners. Also the tolerances on your printer don't have to be great to print this off (which is probably why your printing this in the first place).

comments.text: Yes it fits on the X-axis, I should have put a better image up from the start but I was just lazy. The new cover image shows how it fits on the X-axis belt and how it avoids colliding with the extruder head assembly. It won't bump into the ends as long as you install it on the far right hand side (on the bottom part of the belt), when the extruder is on the far left hand side.

description.text:
This was designed as part of a light defuser for a Christmas decoration, but the result was a bit of a surprise. OpenSCAD's linear_extrude() added facets to the result in an interesting and attractive way, especially when printed using a shiny material. I used translucent PETG but PLA should work as well.

For OpenSCAD-wise folks: I've provided knobs for height, the radius at the base, and the number of points in the star that is extruded. You can adjust the faceting by changing the $fn value for the linear_extrude. (Set it to 512 to see the result I originally expected.) There are other things you can play with, such as the angle of the twist (you'll need to adjust the rotation of the hollow form as well) or the depth of the furrows (i.e. the length of the star points).

The star polygon was my first foray into recursively-defined shapes; feel free to steal it.

title: Firefly 150
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi flying folk and future quadcopter racers. This is the new firefly 150 it is inspired by the famous vortex 150. It is designed to deliver a unique flying experience in yet a so small form factor.
If you like the design but don't want to build

It is still a work in progress so bare with me if some parts aren't perfect.

Along these lines I have to point out that this is a really tight build and that it might be challenging for a first time builder.
I may make an instructables for build clarification.

So far I have collected a list of parts that are compatible with the firefly 150 and a list with all the necessary hardware to assemble the frame.

Hardware

You'll need some additional parts to assemble the frame:
Bolts:

6x M2x10mm
4x M2x6mm
http://www.banggood.com/200pcs-M2-Allen-Bolt-Hex-Socket-Round-Cap-Head-Screw-Assortment-Kit-Set-Black-p-1041363.html?p=BQ31181713038201505L

16x M3x6mm
http://www.banggood.com/Diatone-M3x6-Inner-Hexagon-Screw-Pack-20pcs-For-RC-Multirotors-p-973474.html?p=BQ31181713038201505L

Standoff:
8x M3x8mm standoffs (brass or nylon: female to female)
Brass:
http://www.banggood.com/50pcs-M3-Brass-Female-Threaded-Hex-Standoffs-Spacer-Nut-4681012mm-p-1043793.html?p=BQ31181713038201505L
Nylon:
http://www.banggood.com/300pcs-M3-Nylon-Black-Hex-Scre-p-984310.html?p=BQ31181713038201505L

Required printed parts to build the frame:
1x Top plate
1x Lower plate
1x Canopy
1x Rear (antenna mount)
1x Front fence
1x Sides
4x arm
4x Arm esc mount (Brass or Nylon depends on you) hex

Electronics

I invested a lot of time in searching for the right components for this build. The main reason was the limited space. As far as I know there are no escs out the that would fit the esc mount with a higher current rating then 7A so I gave you some options in the ESC topic for alternative options.
Also don't miss out on the misc section.

remixed_from.author: TysonL
remixed_from.title: ViKi LCD freestanding case mount - mounting bezel

description.text:
I'm tired of having my LCD on the floor or on a shelf when it could just as easily be mounted to the Robo 3D.  This is my relatively crude attempt to make a case off LCD mount.  Technically, with a long enough screw, this works with the case on.  
I printed mine at 10% infill, 0.3mm layer height.  Because this piece has long straights, it's a good part to test high speed printing with.  I printed the Bezel at 90mm/sec.  
To install, Bolt it to the Robo, stick the tab down with sticky tape and mount the LCD.

description.text:
A simple mount to hold a Pi Camera to a Raspberry Pi Zero.

The camera is attached using M2 bolts, preferably nylon as metal bolts could short the Pi.

The Pi is attached using M2.5 bolts. In my photos I used M3 bolts because I didn't have any M2.5 bolts available. If you want to use M3 bolts you will need to use a drill bit to make the mounting holes in the Pi and the printed parts larger.

remixed_from.author: devonjones
remixed_from.title: OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Wooden Floors

description.text:
1st of the series OpenLock adaptors Corner Wood. I'll follow with the rest of the series.
The corner adapter came about, because I needed a 1' wide catwalk/mezzanine and wanted to match the typical A wall on the outside. (thus the "notches" on the bottom to fit the corbel/braces in the corner for the murder holes tiles) The corner adapter also works with the Spiral Corner Stair wood(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149672) to help match up to the standard E tile dungeon layout or as the second floor penetration. Also the corner adapter is good to integrate into the dungeon E style layout as a 1x1 floor penetration (with a ladder or rope) or standard Openlock 1x1 dungeon fixtures trapdoors, traps, columns etc.
